quoteFirst: In the moonlit valley below could be seen the little fishing village of Horejos. I examined my watch and discovered that it wanted
quoteLast: o'clock. Needless to say, I profoundly hoped that Ferguson had received my message, and that we should find the boat awaiting us.
title: The Kidnapped President
author: Boothby, Guy, 1867-1905; Wood, Stanley L., 1866-1928 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The rain ceased just as we came home, but it went on pouring frequently. Albert returned at
quoteLast: , having had very hard work on the moors, wading up to his knees in bogs every now and then, and had killed nine brace of grouse. We lunched; then we went to the drawing-room, and saw from the window the Highlanders dancing reels; but unfortunately it rained the whole time.
title: Leaves From the Journal of Our Life in the Highlands, From 1848 to 1861
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Helps, Arthur, Sir, 1813-1875 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Newton spent the time from twelve-thirty to half after two in watching the clock; and
quoteLast: found him seated in the woodshed with a pen-knife in his hand, a small vial of strychnine crystals on a stand before him, a saucer of raisins at his right hand, and one exactly like it, partially filled with gopher bait--by which is meant raisins under the skin of each of which a minute crystal of strychnine had been inserted on the point of the knife.
title: The Brown Mouse
author: Quick, Herbert, 1861-1925

quoteLast: , as the square marble clock upon the mantel showed, and immediately, before Julia Daly and Morton Sims spoke again, two people came into the room.
title: The Drunkard
author: Thorne, Guy, 1875-1923

quoteLast: , with a load of pollen under their bellies!” I had released my insects at about two o’clock; these first arrivals had therefore flown two miles and a half in less than three quarters of an hour, and lingered to forage on the way.
title: Insect Adventures
author: Fabre, Jean-Henri, 1823-1915; Zimm, Louise Hasbrouck, 1883-; Goldberg, Elias, 1886-1978 [Illustrator]; Teixeira de Mattos, Alexander, 1865-1921 [Translator]

quoteFirst: A fine snow pelted my face.  I stopped at the first lamp and pulled out my watch.  It was
quoteLast: .  What if the time-tables had been changed?  A prayer rose to my lips; there was so much in the balance.  Down this street I ran, rounding this corner and that.  I knocked down a drunken student, who cursed me as he rolled into the gutter.  I never turned, but kept on.
title: Arms and the Woman
author: MacGrath, Harold, 1871-1932

quoteFirst: The raiders were brought up from Gordon Camp in buses, and, after an issue of rum at advanced Battalion Headquarters, formed up on a tape in No Man’s Land about 150 yards from the enemy’s trench (the total distance between the opposing trench lines being 240 yards). At zero hour,
quoteLast: , our artillery put down a barrage on the German front trenches for one minute, and then lifted it on to the support trenches, where it was maintained during the raid. At the same time two separate barrages were dropped on either flank, while suspected saps, machine-guns, and communication trenches had a standing barrage of Newton trench mortars and howitzers directed on them.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: At three o’clock! And the hands of the great clock in the right wing of the castle now marked
quoteLast: . In spite of herself, her eyes wandered to the clock every minute. She also watched Velmont, who was calmly swinging to and fro in a comfortable rocking chair.
title: The Extraordinary Adventures of Arsène Lupin, Gentleman-Burglar
author: Leblanc, Maurice, 1864-1941

quoteLast: when Marjorie finished a remarkable concoction of nuts, chocolate syrup and ice cream, a kind of glorified nut sundae, rejoicing in the name of "Sargent Nectar," and left the smart little confectioner's shop. As she neared the school building her eyes suddenly became riveted upon a slim, blue-clad figure that hesitated for on instant at the top of the high steps then ran lightly down and came hurrying toward where she stood.
title: Marjorie Dean, High School Freshman
author: Chase, Josephine, -1931

quoteLast: we came to a rude heap of stones called _Zoghal_ or _Zoghar_.  This cannot well be Zoar, among other reasons, because it lies upon the beach, and is not upon an eminence.
title: Byeways in Palestine
author: Finn, James, -1872

quoteFirst: She had left her room at a quarter past twelve. Freddie’s evidence pointed to her coming back again at
quoteLast: in the morning, and switching on her light as she re-entered her room. What could any girl be doing out of her bed at that time of night, and for two hours at a stretch? And, undoubtedly, from the evidence of Douglas, the Talisman might have disappeared during the time she was moving about the house.
title: The Dangerfield Talisman
author: Connington, J. J., 1880-1947

quoteFirst: The walls are of different colours, here white, there dark red, and there yellow with sulphur. We go to see the Pohutu Geyser, which formerly twice a day sent a majestic column of water high into the air for from
quoteLast: hours at a time. But today Pohutu sulks and is entirely unreliable, though a way has been found to make it perform on demand. When some distinguished visitor comes along, the officials give the geyser an emetic of several barrels of soap, and then it plays up in great style.
title: Australia, New Zealand and some islands of the South seas
author: Carpenter, Frank G. (Frank George), 1855-1924

quoteFirst: The weather last Sunday was dreadfully inclement. I have seen ten funerals kept waiting in the church-yard from
quoteLast: -quarters of an hour. I have known colds caught on the ground by parties kept waiting, and more probably occurred than I could know of.
title: A supplementary report on the results of a special inquiry into the practice of interment in towns.
author: Chadwick, Edwin, 1800-1890

quoteFirst: When Séverine reached the Rue Cardinet at
quoteLast: , to keep her appointment with Jacques, she found herself before her time. He occupied a small room right at the top of a great house, to which he only ascended at night for the purpose of sleeping.
title: The Monomaniac (La bête humaine)

quoteLast: , and proceeded over a level plain south by west, along the line of telegraph posts. The plain is girt on all sides by high hills, and presents a green sheet of corn-fields and meadows, over which are scattered many villages.
title: From the Indus to the Tigris
